awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Cybersecurity Research of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University. This project focuses on cybersecurity research for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). In each summer, ten undergraduate students will participate in research for eight weeks to understand cybersecurity challenges for UAVs, and how to design algorithms and techniques to protect UAVs from cyber-attacks. This program will provide a research experience with a balance of theory, hands-on practical skills, and applications. The project is led by a team of experienced faculty who will mentor the participating researchers through a number of professional development activities that prepare them for future careers as professionals in the field of cybersecurity and UAVs, which are areas of critical need for the workforce of the future. This project will provide great opportunities for undergraduate students, especially for those from underrepresented and minority groups and institutions with limited research resources, to be involved in real-world cybersecurity research of UAVs. This project will conduct a nationwide recruitment process with particular emphasis on the southeast region of the United States.

The objective of this REU site is to involve undergraduate students to integrate fundamental and state-of-the-art cybersecurity research using UAVs as the platform. Students will understand and study cyber-attacks targeted at UAVs and investigate corresponding cyber defenses. Research activities in this project will explore the cybersecurity of UAVs from multiple angles, including secure communication, data privacy protection, secure control systems for autonomous UAVs, etc. By conducting diverse but coherent research projects, students will gain in-depth understanding and hands-on experience in cybersecurity research for UAVs, as well as general computer and data security.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The REU site Cybersecurity Research of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles completed three eight-week programs during the summer months of 2018, 2019, and 2020. The goals of this REU site were to attract undergraduate students to perform research in cybersecurity and UAVs, especially those from underrepresented and minority groups; teach undergraduate students research methodology; and motivate and prepare participants to be involved in more advanced research. A total of 32 participants have been served to achieve the project goals, of which 59.4% (19/32) are from underrepresented groups (women, Hispanic, or African American), and 34.4% (11/32) are women. Recruiting efforts resulted in a total of 99, 97, and 93 applications for 2018, 2019, and 2020 programs, respectively. The participants in the REU site coauthored five conference papers and two presentations at national or international conferences. Among important results:

  1. The program received diverse and high-quality participant applications, with an overall acceptance rate of 12% (32/289).
  2. Students successfully reported research findings on topics that include security for Wi-Fi-operated UAS, implementing artificial immune systems for UAVs, and security of IEEE 802.11 links using software-defined radios. Seven faculty members mentored a total of 16 projects during the three programs of the site.The participants were exposed to state-of-the-art research capabilities at the John Mica engineering and aerospace innovation complex. Capabilities include unmanned research platforms, a mobile ground control station for UAS operations, robotic arms, sensor packages including LIDAR, 3D cameras for vision navigation, inertial measurement systems, and onboard computers. Furthermore, students were able to implement hardware using PCB manufacturing machines and an anechoic antenna chamber.
  3. To overcome the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic, the REU site pivoted to online delivery during the summer of 2020. During the online delivery of the program, participants remotely performed research tasks while local students at the ERAU Daytona Beach campus served as laboratory proxies for required hands-on manufacturing and testing tasks. 
  4. To the date of this report, among participants that have earned their bachelor’s degrees, seven are pursuing master’s degrees, one pursuing a Ph.D. degree, and seven are working in the industry.

Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: Eduardo Rojas
por.por_txt_cntn:
The REU site Cybersecurity Research of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles completed three eight-week programs during the summer months of 2018, 2019, and 2020. The goals of this REU site were to attract undergraduate students to perform research in cybersecurity and UAVs, especially those from underrepresented and minority groups; teach undergraduate students research methodology; and motivate and prepare participants to be involved in more advanced research. A total of 32 participants have been served to achieve the project goals, of which 59.4% (19/32) are from underrepresented groups (women, Hispanic, or African American), and 34.4% (11/32) are women. Recruiting efforts resulted in a total of 99, 97, and 93 applications for 2018, 2019, and 2020 programs, respectively. The participants in the REU site coauthored five conference papers and two presentations at national or international conferences. Among important results:

The program received diverse and high-quality participant applications, with an overall acceptance rate of 12% (32/289).
Students successfully reported research findings on topics that include security for Wi-Fi-operated UAS, implementing artificial immune systems for UAVs, and security of IEEE 802.11 links using software-defined radios. Seven faculty members mentored a total of 16 projects during the three programs of the site.The participants were exposed to state-of-the-art research capabilities at the John Mica engineering and aerospace innovation complex. Capabilities include unmanned research platforms, a mobile ground control station for UAS operations, robotic arms, sensor packages including LIDAR, 3D cameras for vision navigation, inertial measurement systems, and onboard computers. Furthermore, students were able to implement hardware using PCB manufacturing machines and an anechoic antenna chamber.
To overcome the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic, the REU site pivoted to online delivery during the summer of 2020. During the online delivery of the program, participants remotely performed research tasks while local students at the ERAU Daytona Beach campus served as laboratory proxies for required hands-on manufacturing and testing tasks. 
To the date of this report, among participants that have earned their bachelor’s degrees, seven are pursuing master’s degrees, one pursuing a Ph.D. degree, and seven are working in the industry.
